title: 7 Midwest Governors Announce Partnership to Reopen Economy
summary:
UNDATED -- The Governors of seven Midwestern states -- including Tim Walz of Minnesota -- have announced a partnership to reopen the regional economy.
Besides Minnesota, Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana and Kentucky will work in close coordination.
The governors say they will work with experts and take a ``fact-based, data-driven approach to reopening our economy in a way that protects families from the spread of COVID-19.''
It doesn't mean our economy will all reopen at once, or that every state will take the same steps at the same time.
Similar pacts were made earlier this week in the Northeast and on the West Coast.

summary:

title: Ticketmaster Changes Refund Policy, Covers Only ‘Canceled’ Events
summary:
While you're worried making sure you have the cash to pay your rent, Ticketmaster quietly changed their refund policy which is going to affect many concertgoers.
StubHub has already changed its refund policy for customers and now it seems Ticketmaster quietly done the same.
Ticketmaster will now only refund "canceled" events, rather than for "postponed" or "rescheduled" events, per Digital Music News.
This is going to make it even more difficult for ticket buyers to get a refund for canceled or postponed events.
If you purchased tickets with insurance however, Ticketmaster will still be giving refunds according to their website:Ticketmaster WebsiteFind out more information on Ticketmaster's new refund policy on their website.

title: Phoenix air marker: Iconic mountain sign getting a refresh on New Year's Day
summary:
MESA, AZ — Members of Gilbert Boy Scout Troop 681 are planning to perform maintenance Wednesday on the iconic "< Phoenix" air marker located on the side of Usery Mountain in northeast Mesa.
The marker was "the brainchild of an eccentric ex-World War II pilot" named Charlie Merritt who was also an Air Explorer scout leader, according to Ranger Brennan Basler with Usery Mountain Regional Park.
Basler told ABC15 scouts began construction on the air maker in 1949 under Merritt's direction.
In 1956, the sign was featured in a newspaper column titled "Teenage Triumphs" and, at the time, was deemed the world's largest air marker.
Basler said, given how it was created, it would be more destructive to Usery Mountain to remove the air marker than to leave it in place.

title: Obituary: Locy Marius Rogers 24 Feb 1929 – 7 April 2020
summary:

title: John J. Juntunen
summary:
IRONWOOD, Mich. - John J. Juntunen, 68, of Ironwood, died on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2020 at Pioneer Apartments in Ironwood.
He was born on Sept. 12, 1951, in Ironwood, son of John A. Juntunen and Goldie (Rintala) Juntunen.
John is survived by his brother, Kenneth Juntunen of Kingman, Arizona, and six nephews, six nieces and numerous cousins.
John attended Central Grade School in Ironwood and graduated from Luther L. Wright High School with the class of 1972.
John was a beloved member of his high school class and loved to entertain at class reunions by telling jokes and doing impressions of famous people, (John Wayne and Dean Martin were his favorites).

title: Church reassigning nonnative missionaries from 23 missions in the Philippines
summary:
SALT LAKE CITY — Nonnative Latter-day Saint missionaries serving in 23 missions in the Philippines are heading back to their home countries for reassignment.
“These missionaries will return to their home countries for new temporary assignments.
They will begin their new assignments after completing a 14-day period of self-isolation at home as a precaution.”The church previously sent home all nonnative missionaries from Mongolia on Feb. 27 and from South Korea on March 5.

title: Ticketmaster Changes Refund Policy, Covers Only ‘Canceled’ Events
summary:
While you're worried making sure you have the cash to pay your rent, Ticketmaster quietly changed their refund policy which is going to affect many concertgoers.
StubHub has already changed its refund policy for customers and now it seems Ticketmaster quietly done the same.
Ticketmaster will now only refund "canceled" events, rather than for "postponed" or "rescheduled" events, per Digital Music News.

title: Gilbert company contributes to Arizona's economic growth
summary:
GILBERT, AZ — While some of President Trump's policies may have helped, Arizona's economic growth is self-made.
In 2012 Yoke Chung and his business partner Troy Swope, at the time engineers at Intel had an idea.
So in 2015, with three other engineers they decided to take on the 220-million dollar plastics industry by creating Footprint.
A company that is now transforming the food industry by replacing plastic food containers with trays, bowls, plates and straws.
"We can expand further in this business park or a different park," Chung says, "It's easier to put things in Arizona."

title: Putting Weight on an Older Horse – The Horse
summary:
Should I switch him to senior feed that would also provide more fat?
Feeding fat is certainly a great way to add more calories to the diet, and if the result is a higher total daily calorie intake, you should see some weight gain.
Certainly, switching to a senior feed with a fairly high fat content is one option.
You can feed fat supplements at the manufacturer’s recommended amount based on your horse’s body weight and how much weight gain is needed.
However, if you feed less than the minimum daily amount of senior feed, continue feeding the ration balancer at approximately half the normal amount.

title: 'American Idol' Suspending Production Due to Coronavirus
summary:
American Idol is suspending production and sending contestants home amid concerns over the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.
According to TV Line, the iconic reality TV singing contest is suspending production effective immediately to ensure that the contestants who have traveled to be on the show are able to get back to their families.
A source tells TV Line that the rest of the production team will continue to work remotely, as they have been doing since last week.
American Idol airs on Sundays and Mondays on ABC, with Luke Bryan, Katy Perry and Lionel Richie serving as the judging panel since ABC launched the reboot in 2018.

title: 7 people arrested in fraudulent car-buying scheme in East Valley
summary:
(Photo: Joe Raedle/Getty Images)State investigators have arrested seven people involved with an operation based in the East Valley that illegally produced thousands of titles for vehicles being sold in 42 states, officials said.
This operation is known as curbstoning, which involves selling vehicles in ways that violate parameters set by a dealer's license.
Curbstoning also involves licensed dealers selling vehicles away from the designated area of sale, according to a release from Arizona Department of Transportation.
The unlicensed dealers often sell the vehicles on street corners or vacant lots.
Many of the vehicles involved were never in Arizona, according to the release.

title: Antiques, art and 15 guns: Gilbert couple arrested on suspicion of theft
summary:
CLOSEChristian Propst, 27, and Margo Barre, 35, were arrested ob suspicion of theft Feb. 18, 2020, in Chandler.
(Photo: Chandler Police Department)A man and woman from Gilbert were arrested in connection with a burglary involving guns and antique art, according to Chandler Police Department spokesman Detective Seth Tyler.

title: northrop grumman satellite facility
summary:
GILBERT, Ariz. – Northrop Grumman Corporation held a groundbreaking ceremony yesterday to highlight its expansion of the company’s satellite engineering and manufacturing operations in Arizona.
The expansion includes a 100,000 square foot addition to its existing satellite manufacturing facility and a new 120,000 square foot administrative and engineering building.
The expansion will double the current production capacity at the satellite manufacturing facility, which is one of the largest and most advanced satellite assembly and test facilities in the United States.

Northrop Grumman’s satellite business began in Gilbert in the early 1990’s.

title: Fire at East Valley landfill facility disrupts cities’ recycling programs
summary:
The recycling facility used by Republic Services at the landfill was destroyed, according to a Friday press release from the town of Fountain Hills.
As a result, the release said, Republic Services has to suspend its recycling services until it can find another place to process recyclable materials.
The Fountain Hills release said the fire was caused by a lithium-ion battery and spread by 60 mph winds.
Gilbert, Mesa and Scottsdale also used the Salt River recycling facility, according the landfill’s website.
A Scottsdale spokesperson said the city took its recyclables to a different recycling facility Friday and was in the process of evaluating its options.

title: Gilbert celebrates 20th anniversary of Riparian Preserve on Oct. 12
summary:
A fisherman enjoys the day at Gilbert's Riparian Preserve at Water Ranch.
Three weeks after opening its newest park, Gilbert Regional Park, Gilbert will celebrate the 20th anniversary of one of its crown jewels, the Riparian Preserve at Water Ranch, on Oct. 12 from 9 a.m.-8 p.m.The seven-pond preserve—the ponds are actually water recharge basins for effluent—at 2757 E. Guadalupe Road in Gilbert serves as an aquifer for the town, but is adorned with trails and wildlife, plus an observatory.Celebration activities start at the adjacent Southeast Regional Library, 775 N. Greenfield Road in Gilbert.
The library will offer story time, crafts, face painting and a prize wheel among its offerings from 9 a.m.-2 p.m.The preserve’s activities will run from 3-8 p.m., with vendor and food booths on site.
The anniversary ceremony will be held at 3:30 p.m. east of the library next to the lake.Other activities include a dinosaur show at 3 p.m., a reptile show at 4 p.m. and solar and night sky viewing at the observatory.
A fishing derby, set to run from 5-6:30 p.m., requires a fishing license and online preregistration to participate.The celebration will finish with night hikes and s’mores from 6:30-8 p.m.

title: KTAR News to partner with Walgreens for free flu shots
summary:
PHOENIX — With flu season on the horizon, health officials are urging people to get their flu shot.
It takes approximately two weeks to develop antibodies to fight the flu after receiving the shot.
By getting the flu shot, people are protecting themselves and their community from influenza.
In partnership with KTAR News 92.3 FM, Walgreens will be providing free flu shots to those without insurance or who are underinsured from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Oct. 25 and Oct. 29 at participating stores.

title: 2 meteor showers will play across the Arizona skies this week
summary:
October opens up the fall meteor shower season with the annual Draconid shower.
This interesting meteor shower will appear all week in our Arizona skies and peak on the nights of Oct. 8-9.
The Draconid meteor shower is known to come from comet 21P/Giacobini–Zinner, discovered back on Dec. 20, 1900.
The other meteor shower that is plowing into our October skies is the annual Southern Taurid meteor shower.
Alert: Look to the early evening and midnight skies for what may be a few very bright fireballs from these two showers.

title: Arizona's 2019 monsoon: When will the heat and rain start?
summary:
The pleasant spring weather we’ve enjoyed in the Phoenix area and throughout Arizona could push back the start of the 2019 Arizona monsoon.
The National Weather Service in Tucson released its 2019 monsoon outlook video on May 30.
As a result, the weather will start to heat up, which should start the shift toward monsoon conditions.
The monsoon feeds on heatThe subtropical high-pressure area that is a catalyst for the wind shift that causes our monsoon conditions needs heat to move into position.
Those storms, particularly in late August and September, can boost the moisture that our monsoon storms feed on.

title: Cases of valley fever in Arizona are up in 2019. Here's what you need to know
summary:
A "grow and blow" climate model ties a wet winter followed by a dry summer with higher-than-normal valley fever numbers.
Here are five things to know about valley fever:65% of all U.S. valley fever cases are in ArizonaIf you have lived in Arizona most of your life, it's highly likely you've already had valley fever.
Maricopa, Pinal and Pima counties have been dubbed a "valley fever corridor" and account for about two-thirds of valley fever cases in the U.S. Another 30% occur in California.
Banner Health began its new valley fever protocol in part because so many Arizona doctors are trained out-of-state and may not be familiar with valley fever.
Also, valley fever symptoms are so similar to pneumonia that published research shows as many as 25% of Arizonans diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia actually have valley fever.

title: Tornado lands in Gilbert on Nov. 29
summary:
High winds and a brief tornado landing did some landscape damage in Gilbert on Nov. 29.
(Tom Blodgett/Community Impact Newspaper)The National Weather Service has confirmed a tornado touched down briefly in Gilbert in the early morning hours of Nov. 29.Based on radar, the weather service believes the tornado touched down at 4:41 a.m. in the area of the Loop 202 and Williams Field Road.Ken Waters, the warning coordination meteorologist for the National Weather Service’s Phoenix office, confirmed the presence of the tornado, along with two others in the Valley, in a preliminary report he filed Friday.Weather service meteorologist Sean Benedict said Friday morning’s large “upper level low” weather system, which came with rain and high winds overnight, caused the tornado.“Anytime you get that system moving close to our area, the dynamics are going to be favorable for that to happen,” he said.
“We also had high winds, and that wind profile can lead to severe weather.”Though a tornado warning was issued for the area of Gilbert, Higley and Apache Junction, Benedict said these particular tornadoes are “quite hard to catch, they pop up so quickly.”The other confirmed tornadoes in the Valley were in Queen Creek and north Phoenix.Only other tornado has been recorded in the Gilbert area, according to www.tornadohistoryproject.com , which has data on tornadoes from 1952.
That tornado touched down in the area of Recker and Power roads on Feb. 13, 1995.

title: Developer has groundbreaking for Verde at Cooley Station
summary:
Town and company officials and partners break ground on the construction site for SB2-Gilbert's Verde at Cooley Station at the southwest corner of Williams Field and Recker roads in Gilbert.
(Tom Blodgett/Community Impact Newspaper)The long-awaited Verde at Cooley Station project reached groundbreaking Nov. 19, opening construction on the linchpin piece to the 650-acre master planned community.Norm Brody, a partner at SB2-Gilbert LLC, the project developer, said Verde at Cooley Station, located on the southwest corner of Williams Field and Recker roads, will be the centerpiece for the overall Cooley Station project.“From the beginning, our development team has been focused on creating a special, exciting, walkable place loaded with unique wall graphics, large-scale sculpture in public spaces and children's play area, where the citizens of Gilbert from 8 to 80 can come together in Verde's public spaces to enhance their lives by participating in community events, enjoying events at our performance venue or dining at an array of restaurants, shopping at a variety of stores or just hanging out," Brody said.The $60 million project includes nearly 150,000 square feet of commercial space and 450 multifamily residential units.
“The Green” will be a common area for community events, entertainment and activities.Another 2,000 apartments and 1,000 single-family homes are under development within a quarter mile of Verde at Cooley Station.The developers have announced the first restaurants to sign a lease: West Alley BBQ, a Tennessee-style barbecue restaurant with live entertainment, and OBON, an Asian dining spot with casual atmosphere.The development also will include Verde Medical Center and has plans for a commuter rail station to bring people between Phoenix and the East Valley.Mayor Jenn Daniels hailed the arrival of the project, saying the community has been looking forward to the project for the past 10 years and that it makes the corner a “real gem” for the community.Daniels also said she appreciated its proximity to Arizona State University’s Polytechnical campus in Mesa.“I really believe that this is the true connector for ASU Poly to the community,” she said.
“I am just so glad that their students will have access to world-class amenities right here and in close proximity.”

title: Tornado lands in Gilbert on Nov. 29
summary:
High winds and a brief tornado landing did some landscape damage in Gilbert on Nov. 29.
(Tom Blodgett/Community Impact Newspaper)The National Weather Service has confirmed a tornado touched down briefly in Gilbert in the early morning hours of Nov. 29.Based on radar, the weather service believes the tornado touched down at 4:41 a.m. in the area of the Loop 202 and Williams Field Road.Ken Waters, the warning coordination meteorologist for the National Weather Service’s Phoenix office, confirmed the presence of the tornado, along with two others in the Valley, in a preliminary report he filed Friday.Weather service meteorologist Sean Benedict said Friday morning’s large “upper level low” weather system, which came with rain and high winds overnight, caused the tornado.“Anytime you get that system moving close to our area, the dynamics are going to be favorable for that to happen,” he said.
“We also had high winds, and that wind profile can lead to severe weather.”Though a tornado warning was issued for the area of Gilbert, Higley and Apache Junction, Benedict said these particular tornadoes are “quite hard to catch, they pop up so quickly.”The other confirmed tornadoes in the Valley were in Queen Creek and north Phoenix.Only other tornado has been recorded in the Gilbert area, according to www.tornadohistoryproject.com , which has data on tornadoes from 1952.
That tornado touched down in the area of Recker and Power roads on Feb. 13, 1995.

title: Police impersonator pulls over citizen in Gilbert
summary:
GILBERT, AZ — A man impersonating a police officer pulled over a citizen in Gilbert, according to court records.
Gilbert police report that on December 6, a citizen called 911 saying he was being pulled over near the US 60 and Gilbert Road by a personal car with red and blue flashing lights.
The car, driven by Michael Albao Perez, 47, left the area and returned home, followed by the victim and police.
Perez was seen by police wearing a shirt with the word "police" on the back.
It's unclear if Perez had attempted to pull over any other citizens in the past or if this was the only victim.

title: Mother does not bring 2 missing Idaho children to police by deadline
summary:

Larry Woodcock, the biological grandfather of JJ, told ABC News' Amy Robach earlier Thursday that he did not think Vallow would show up with the children.
He was later pronounced dead, and a spokesperson for Gilbert police previously told ABC News the department still was waiting for autopsy results to determine the cause.

The fast-food restaurant is located at 2800 E. Germann Road, near Gilbert and Germann roads, in the former "Slim Chickens" building.
The opening will mark Jollibee's 40th restaurant in the United States.
Jollibee said it plans to grow to 150 stores in the U.S. and to 100 stores in Canada by 2023.
Other Jollibee locations in the U.S. are in California, Florida, Hawaii, Illinois, Nevada, New Jersey, New York, Texas, Washington, and Virginia.

The male suspect, Christian Propst, 27, knew the couple who rented the units — they were friends of his family, according to court documents.

title: Phoenix's biggest weather events of 2019 didn't involve heat. Here's what they were
summary:
While high temperature records have been common recently, Phoenix experienced something rare last winter when it shattered a 122-year-old record for the lowest daily high temperature.
The average high temperature for February (63.6 degrees) was 7.1 degrees below normal.
Summer was hot, but not that hotThere were no eye-catching high temperatures in 2019 — nothing like the 122-degree high Phoenix experienced on June 26, 1990.
That wouldn’t even crack the top five on the city’s all-time high temperature list.
The city also saw six high temperature records either beaten or tied during the spring and summer, in addition to five records for warmest overnight low temperatures.

title: No burning allowed on New Year's Eve or New Year's Day in Maricopa County
summary:
(Photo: Anchiy, Getty Images/iStockphoto)Those looking to ring in the new year next to a cozy fireplace will have to find an alternative, as authorities declared New Year's Eve and New Year's Day no-burn days in Maricopa County.
Officials issued a High Pollution Advisory for Dec. 31 and Jan. 1, according to the Maricopa County Air Quality Department.
The department said there should be no wood burning, leaf-blowing or off-roading vehicles on those days, adding that air quality in the county would be unhealthy for sensitive groups.
MORE: Maricopa County has gotten hundreds of complaints on no-burn daysThose wanting to report a violation of the order can reach the department's hotline at 602-372-2703 or fill out an online form.
But even when no-burn days are in effect, consequences are rare.

title: Gilbert's population estimates up again in latest American Community Survey 5-year data
summary:
Gilbert's population continues to grow, according to the latest American Community Survey five-year profile.
(Courtesy Town of Gilbert)The Hispanic or Latino population was 40,203.
That makes up 16.9% of the whole population, up about 1.3% from 2014, according to the data.
The town of Gilbert grew 6.43% in the five years from 2014-18, according to U.S. Census Bureau data released Dec. 19 in the 2018 American Community Survey 5-year profile.That estimate brings the town’s 2018 population to 237,484, according to the survey.
People identifying themselves as biracial or multiracial grew about a half-percent as a part of the whole, as did those categorizing themselves as “other race.” The black population grew about 0.3% to 3.63%.

title: Meet the Jollibee superfan who's been camped at the Chandler restaurant since Christmas
summary:
From the outside, the new Jollibee in Chandler looks much like any other fast food restaurant.
FOR SUBSCRIBERS: Why iconic Filipino restaurant Jollibee is coming to ChandlerUntil now, Arizonans on the hunt for a Yum burger had to drive to California or Nevada for the nearest Jollibee restaurant.
"It's an amazing experience," Irene Daguio Ballesteros-Shields says as she eagerly awaits opening day at Arizona's first Jollibee restaurant in Chandler.
Employees told Ballesteros-Shields about a customer in Calgary, Canada, who camped out for two days before the Jollibee opening.
Why she's camping out for JollibeeBallesteros-Shields moved to Arizona in 1993 and has been waiting for a Jollibee restaurant to open ever since.

title: Gilbert Mayor Jenn Daniels announces she won't seek second term. Another contender steps up almost immediately
summary:
CLOSEJenn Daniels (Photo: Jenn Daniels/Special for The Republic)Gilbert Mayor Jenn Daniels announced Monday morning that she will not run for reelection.
Prior to that, she served on the Town Council from 2009 to 2016.
“I have loved the nearly 11 years I have spent serving Gilbert,” Daniels wrote in a tweet on her personal account.
Daniels filed for divorce from her husband of nearly 20 years in October, according to Maricopa County Superior Court records.
Peterson, who has served on the Town Council since 2015, said she "officially learned today" that Daniels won't seek reelection.

title: Past two months in Phoenix were cloudiest November and December in nearly 20 years
summary:
The past two months were the cloudiest November and December in Phoenix in at least 19 years.
Isaac Smith, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service, said multiple weather systems moved through the area this fall and winter, bringing rainfall.
On average, Phoenix is cloudy about 38% of the time during the last two months of the year.
Phoenix is one of the sunniest cities in the United States, according to NOAA data.
Tucson and Flagstaff also are among the sunniest cities in the country.

title: THIS WEEKEND: Pet adoption event at Horne Kia in Gilbert
summary:
Horne KIA is holding an adoption event on Saturday, December 14, where you can bring home a dog or a cat that is looking for a forever home this holiday season.
The event will also include a chance to win raffle prizes and take a picture with Santa for a small donation.
The “Sebastian’s Santa Cause” event is being organized by Sebastian's Second Chance Felines and The FARM Rescue, along with Horne KIA, Horne Motors, Horne Hyundai and Horne Ford.
To be able to bring these families hope and joy this Christmas truly embodies not only our Horne values, but our commitment to supporting community,” said Josh Bauman, General Manager of Horne Kia.
It will be held at 1465 E Motorplex Loop, Gilbert, AZ 85297 from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. For more information, call (480) 725-5220.

title: Flagstaff, northern Arizona to see more snow; difficult travel conditions expected
summary:

That's what Beth Stull wrote on Twitter as she watched nearly a foot of snow fall in Flagstaff.
Much of Arizona had a white day-before-Christmas and a white day-after-Christmas, too.
With temperatures deep below freezing — Flagstaff had a low of 6 degrees and a high of 28 on Thursday — and several inches of snow expected overnight Thursday plus more on Friday morning, travel was expected to become "very difficult," according to the National Weather Service.

title: Officials confirm Buckeye funnel cloud as rain sweeps Valley, snow blankets northern Arizona
summary:
CLOSEA cold, wet storm swept across Arizona on Friday, bringing rain, snow and even a funnel cloud over Buckeye.
While rain was expected to clear by Saturday, weather officials say more rain is possible early next week.
A cold-air funnel cloud formed in Buckeye as the Valley experienced cool temperatures and a bit of rain on Friday, officials confirmed.
The funnel cloud did not touch down, but did form near Baseline Road and Wilson Avenue for a brief period, National Weather Service meteorologist Derek Hodges said.
Phoenix had only seen about 0.01 inches of rain by 10:15 a.m., according to National Weather Service meteorologist Austin Jamison.
